Message.Title: Why Windows 8 Won't Matter For Many Large Companies
Message.Msg: If this weren't so tragic, it would be funny. I can't resist pointing out the logical implication: For 80% of companies, it would be no harder to migrate to Linux than to migrate to Windows 8. http://www.forbes.com/sites/timworstall/2012/07/30/why-windows-8-wont-matter-for-many-large-companies/?partner=yahootix Tim Worstall, Contributor I write about business and technology. Follow (177) Tech | 7/30/2012 @ 12:32PM |928 views Why Windows 8 Won't Matter For Many Large Companies I have to admit this rather surprised me but it does seem that the upcoming Windows 8 just isn’t going to be an issue at all for many large users. This includes private sector companies as well as public sector users over in the UK. The reason being that many of them haven’t made it to Windows Vista yet, let alone 7, and so just aren’t in the upgrade path leading to Windows 8. Windows 7 is running in just 20 per cent of large enterprises with the most difficult migrations yet to come. That’s according to web browser specialist Browsium, which said 80 per cent of big companies – those with 10,000 or more PCs – are still clinging to Windows XP even though support for it is due to end in two years. But IT department bosses fear the cost, difficulty and disruption of moving business-critical apps from Microsoft’s Internet Explorer 6 and 7, which are off-limits on Windows 7. The reason for this is more than just a little delicious. Back in the days of Windows XP there was a great deal of effort made to encourage software written to perform in Internet Explorer. Apps and so on. Many companies did exactly this and wrote their basic systems within this environment. The encouragement came from Microsoft of course as it locked those users into the entire Windows experience. For apps written to take advantage of the ways and times in which Explorer deviated from the standards were apps that would not be easily portable to other browsers. And if they can’t go to other browsers then clearly not to other operating systems underneath. But now that Microsoft is releasing operating systems that do not support IE 6 and 7, and most certainly do not support those off standard things which the apps are using, this is stopping users from migrating their OS up the series as Microsoft would like them to. For it would actually require entire system rewrites to do so. And as many companies are quite rightly concluding, if you’ve got a system that works then why on earth would you want to do that? I find this amusing myself: Microsoft’s efforts a decade ago to make sure that people did not leave Microsoft have led to the company now losing two and possibly three sets of upgrade fees as a result.

Message.Title: Samsung leaving Android for Windows Phone 8??
Message.Msg: http://www.benzinga.com/news/12/07/2787448/is-samsung-leaving-android-for-windows-phone-8#ixzz228Guzvwr Is Samsung Leaving Android for Windows Phone 8? Louis Bedigian, Benzinga Staff Writer July 30, 2012 1:57 PM Samsung is planning to release two Windows Phone 8 devices in 2012, signaling the end of a near-exclusive relationship with Google's (NASDAQ: GOOG) Android platform. According to The Verge, information on the new devices came from court documents that were submitted as part of the ongoing battle between Apple and Samsung. The first phone, currently referred to as the "Odyssey," comes with a dual-core 1.5GHz processor from Qualcomm (NASDAQ: QCOM), and is apparently described as an "iconic smartphone" with 4G LTE. (How can something be iconic before it is even released?) Odyssey will also feature a 4.65-inch Super AMOLED display (high-def, of course), as well as an 8MP rear camera. According to The Verge, the device may also support the Wallet Hub and Tap + Send features of Windows Phone 8. Samsung's other device, currently referred to as "Marco," will reportedly feature a four-inch Super AMOLED display, and will also support 4G LTE. While this unofficial announcement is good news for Microsoft (NASDAQ: MSFT), which no longer has to rely on Nokia (NYSE: NOK) to save its Windows Phone 8 platform, it could greatly impact the company's relationship with Google. Samsung may not have any plans to drop Android. The company may fully intend to release the Galaxy S IV exclusively on Android next year. But if its Windows Phone 8 experiment proves to be successful, Samsung will have to make a choice when it comes time to develop its best next-gen phones. The company will not be able to make all of them for Android. Thus, Android may end up missing out on phones that it could have had if Samsung had avoided Windows Phone 8 development. But the consequences will not end there. By developing for the Windows Phone 8 platform, Samsung has given an official thumbs-up to Microsoft's latest mobile OS. In doing so, other smartphone manufacturers are bound to take notice. When that happens, Android could continue to lose. Just as the market shifted to Android from other platforms, it could soon shift from Android to Windows Phone 8. For now, however, Android can celebrate the fact that its Samsung-manufactured devices have outsold the iPhone by more than 20 million units. Apple is having a bit of a celebration as well. Earlier this month, ChangeWave Research revealed that iPhone 5 demand is through the roof, breaking all records set by the previous iPhones, including the iPhone 4S. . Motorola said it was not immediately anticipating an impact on operations and added that it will explore appeal options, according to the Wall Street Journal. Microsoft has also enforced an injunction against the Google unit in the U.S. after the U.S. International Trade Commission granted it the right to do in a case related to a technology that syncs entries in software features. According to Florian Mueller of FOSS patents, Motorola is the only major Android device maker that has not taken a patent license from Microsoft.
